title: Are male teachers allowed to enter female students' toilets? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are male teachers allowed to enter female students' toilets? In the United States, this is a toilet:  The room where that is, in public, is called a “restroom.” If it’s in your house, it’s commonly called the “bathroom,” even if it doesn’t have a bath in it.  Anyway… Are male teachers allowed to enter the female students’ restroom? Not under normal circumstances. A male teacher may enter in an emergency, such as: A report of a student getting very sick or self-harming in the bathroom.A fight breaks out in the bathroom.There is a lockdown and it’s the nearest room with a lock.A male teacher may not go into the female students’ restroom just to make sure the students aren’t wasting time or to look for a student who he thinks may be skipping class. In those cases, the male teacher would just ask a female teacher to handle it. We’re always told that, as long as we’re doing something that any prudent, sane adult would do in any given situation, we’re legally covered and the school district will defend us with its lawyers if it comes down to it. So, if I’m walking down the hall and I hear someone screaming like they’re being attacked in the girls’ restroom, I’m not only allowed to go in an investigate, but it would be odd if I didn’t. The same thing goes for touching a student in an emergency, for what it’s worth. Normally, touching a student is a huge no-no. However, if a student breaks their ankle or something during recess, like any prudent, sane adult, I can pick up the child and take them off of the playground until help arrives.

response.answer_text: There is a built-in, unfair attitude about this in our culture. Female nurses can give all sorts of personal care to a male patient, and nobody will think a thing of it. However, if a female patient receives care from a male nurse, the patient may feel embarrassed or threatened and request a replacement. The same thing happens in teaching. A female teacher can go into the boys’ restroom and there will be nothing thought of it. She might also give a little boy help with his zipper, and nobody would think a thing of it. If I went into a girls’ restroom, or if I helped a little girl with her clothing anywhere near her private areas, you can bet that there would be complaints. If I heard a fight in the girls’ restroom, thought a girl might be ill, or if a girl needed help with her clothing, I would immediately go to the nearest classroom with a female teacher. I would say, “There’s a fight in the girls’ restroom. Please check on it. I’ll watch your class.” I know a janitor who was fired and also sent to jail. As kids went through the line in the cafeteria to dump the garbage from their trays, he would sometimes pick them up and pretend he was going to put them in the garbage can. One day, a cop showed up at school. Several fourth grade girls had complained that he had fondled their breasts while doing this. It did not matter that the cooks were right there and had never seen such a thing, or that the principal, the teacher assigned lunchroom duty, and two parent volunteers had never seen such a thing. He went to jail, lost his pension, and lost his reputation. Think about this. If you have ever picked up a child, where were your thumbs? Even if you were totally innocent, could your thumbs have brushed the sides of fourth grade girls’ breasts? Like it or not, we live in a sue-happy society, and you do not have to do anything wrong to get in trouble.

I would imagine the rules are about the same as they are for most male/female type things - not normally but if it is an emergency. So if I were a teacher at a school, and someone came running up to me saying “Susie’s collapsed in the toilet” then I wouldn’t go “Well she’s going to have to die because I am male and cannot possibly enter the girls’ toilets” - that would be insane and crazy making. And if the school is being evacuated due to a bomb threat, and for whatever reason I couldn’t find a female teacher to search the girls’ loos then I would go in and search them to make sure they are empty. But on a day to day basis I wouldn’t go in because why would I need to? And if I did need to I would make every effort to find a female member of staff to do whatever was needed first, and then only go in if I had to. But if it is a choice between letting someone suffer, or not then there’s really no contest. I can’t let someone die just because I am a guy - that would be insane.

Only in a few very unusual or extreme circumstances. If there is no one else in there and I have reason to suspect that there is something wrong. For example, if something has been stolen from my classroom and I’ve checked everywhere else. Even in this case, I’d try to send someone else in to check. Maybe if it were late at night and there was no one else available in the building? This would require some extremely unusual circumstances where I couldn’t find backup.If there is an obvious reason to believe that there is an emergency situation, like if a student ran into my classroom saying “x cut herself in the bathroom and needs medical help”, or if there were obvious signs of a fight occurring. Once again, I’d do whatever I could to make sure that I had backup, but for an immediate concern I’d probably go in and send the student to get a second teacher.That’s about it. I can’t imagine another reason why I would ever want to, or need to, go into the girl’s bathroom.

No. At our school male teachers were only allowed in mens bathrooms/locker rooms but females were allowed in both mens and women's locker rooms/bathrooms. I remember one time a girl slipped in the locker room and hurt her leg and our Male teacher had to go get a female to check up on her. As for female teachers it wasnt uncommon to see them come in boys locker room or bathrooms. One time our Male teacher wasnt available and we had a substitute gym teacher who was a female she came inside the locker room to do attendance while boys were changing/showering and sometimes there would be female teachers or college student teachers come inside to set up posters or take some down. People might say it's a double standard but none of us boys felt threatened by them coming in like girls would if men came in to their locker rooms

Certainly not at the school that I went to. I remember one time, we were at the local lake for PE (we were doing water sports that term) and one of my classmates decided to pretend that she had slipped and broken her ankle while she was getting changed. The teacher wasn’t fooled for a minute, but according to the rules, he wasn’t allowed to go in and get her. In the end, another teacher had to drive over from the school just to go into the loo and make sure that she was lying.

Are male teachers allowed to enter female students' toilets? Just to set the hearts of some other correspondents at rest, In some countries, rooms at schools where people go to “relieve themselves” by making use of a toilet is known as either the “girls’ toilet(s)”, or the “boys’ toilet(s)”. (At other public facilities, and restaurants, we talk of the “men’s / women's’ toilet(s)”.) A male is not allowed in the girls’ / women's’ toilets, under ordinary circumstances, as detailed by others.

Are male teachers allowed to enter female students' toilets? I don’t suppose male teachers want to go in the girls’ restrooms. Under some circumstances, they might forego that reluctance. In general, though, the answer is no. Most of the time, they would ask a female colleague to check out anything they considered suspicious.

According to current law and government guidelines any teacher identifying as female must use the bathroom assigned to females. You can’t expect them to use the other facility. In some cases the bathrooms are marked for universal access for use by anyone identifying as any gender.

Only in immediate emergencies. Normally, they are supposed to find a female teacher or a (preferably female) security guard. In my school, a male teacher once ordered a female student to go check on her classmate exactly because of this reason.
